_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Matt Brewing Company, its management and its employees are committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, neighbors and the community.  As such, the Matt Brewing Company has established procedures for the safe operation of its Facility and its processes.  Included in these procedures is a Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management policies that include methods to ensure the Facility's use of Anhydrous Ammonia in its refrigeration system complies with federal and state safety and risk management requirements.  These procedures help to ensure that systems are in place to prevent accidental releases, and to manage them if they occur.   



The Facility's operations include brewing and bottling/canning of malt beverages and sodas.  As part of its operations, the Facility uses a closed loop Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system to maintain appropriate temperatures for brewing and storage.  This assures that no Ammonia is released from the system unless there is a leak or an accidental release.  The Facility currently uses 18,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia in its refrigeration system.  The Facility has not had to purchase any Anhydrous Ammonia in over five years, because the anhydrous ammonia system is a closed loop system and there have been no accidental releases.  



The Facility operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.  At all times a responsible Ammonia Refrigerant Engineer is on-site to respond to any accidental releases, leaks, or concerns.  All employees that work with, or around, the Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system have regularly scheduled training, and additional training when there are any changes - or it is otherwise deemed to be appropriate. The Facility's Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system is fully mapped out, pipes are painted different colors with directional markings and information about contents and pressures. Valves are also identified by tagging. 



An automatic system is used that detects and respond

s to a leak and/or accidental release.  A backup manual system can also be used if necessary.  A venting system automatically turns on in the event a spill or leak of Anhydrous Ammonia is detected, and a notice is sent automatically to the Boiler Room's main computer, the Engineer staff's smart phone as well as to personal phones.  If the venting does not control the leak, alarms are sent out.  If necessary, the Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system can be shut down from either the boiler room's computer or the emergency stop buttons at any of 3 entrances to the engine room.  In addition there are automatic valves installed on the two condensers located on the Facility's roof, which work with the system to control pressure.



In case of an accidental release of Anhydrous Ammonia from the Facility, the Facility has emergency response procedures in place that include coordination with local emergency responders thereby providing notification to the community.  To ensure the local emergency responders and Facility personnel are prepared, the Facility has conducted both table-top and full scale drills, and participates at regular meetings, with local emergency responders.
